testimony: Good morning everybody, we'll be proceeding with the hearing with the evidence of Mr Hardien.  Ms Coleridge?

	Mr Hardien, can you tell the Committee how did you come into contact with Mr Slang van Zyl?
I made contact with Mr van Zyl through Peaches.
He contacted me, we met each other.

I asked him why he had my name and address and he said I mustn't worry, it is not important.  We had a discussion and we met each again.
I cannot recall, I do not know.

	Then the last thing, just in terms of background, what is your level of education?

	Now you've informed us that you had met Mr Slang van Zyl, now regarding the second time you had met him, what did he inform you as to, what does he need or require from you, how were you going to help him?  Can you explain that to us?
He told me that I know Kewtown, I knew everything that was going on there, I can assist him to prevent the ANC from coming in.

And then what did he inform you after that?  Was he going to contact you again, or were you going to contact him?  What did he inform you as to how you're going to build relations between the two of you?
He told me that he'd contact me again and that I can contact him as well.
And then, did you contact him?

We just met as we did before, we had a discussion, I think there were a lot of activities going on, I think it was in that time, yes, and who the people were who were involved, the arsonists or the arson, etcetera.
Right.  Did Mr van Zyl offer you any money in terms of getting you to contact him and so forth?
Just in your one statement you had stated that you were paid about R400 or R500, just in terms of contacting Mr van Zyl telephonically and so forth, can you remember that?
I can remember it because it was money that I received from him.
And can you inform us, what was your first operation that Mr Slang van Zyl required you to do for him?
I had to give him information about who the people were.
Is that the people regarding the Athlone Kewtown Youth Movement?
How did you gather that information regarding the Kewtown Youth Movement?
I know them all, I know what they do.
Good.  What report-back did you give to Mr van Zyl regarding the Kewtown Youth Movement?
I told him that they were involved in the arson in Belgravia Road.
And how did you know that information?
It is very simple, I operate with them, I move around in the area.
Now your first operation you were involved in the South West African ... just before the elections, can you explain to us what Mr van Zyl had required you to do there?
I would just like to ask a question.  He asked me if I wanted to go on holiday or if I've been on holiday.   I said no.
And then how was it that you got to go to South West Africa?
He told me then that I can go to South West Africa.
I can spend a few days there because people from the Cape will come up for meetings or business or whatever happened there and I then went.
Were you required to take down people's registration numbers, from buses or cars or so forth?
How many times did you go to South West Africa?
Sorry, what kind of people were these that you were supposed to go and look at registration numbers of, from the Cape?
I just had to observe registration numbers.
Yes, well were they from any particular political organisation or ... what was the whole object, why were you going to look at registration numbers?
I assume it was political people, because there was an election, there was a meeting or an election or whatever.
So you didn't really know who these people were or what they were doing, you didn't even know why you had to take these registration numbers?

But if you go to Windhoek and sit on the pavement in the main road, thousands of vehicles are going to pass you, you're just going to write down registration numbers of every vehicle in Windhoek?  What's the point of that?

No, I arrived there and they told me - I cannot remember the name, just don't ask me the names because then you'll never get an answer, they told me to sit at a specific spot and that cars will come and taxis will come and I had to remain at that specific spot.
In your statement here you say it was Church Street in Windhoek.
Yes, that's the main street, if I'm correct.
I'm not sure that it was the main street, because you couldn't find the place.  You'd think that you'd easily find a main street.
It was the street where the hotel was.  I think that was in the main street.
Mr Hardien, you said you didn't got to school, can you read and write?
Are you capable of seeing a registration number of a vehicle and writing it down?
You can do that, although you can't ...
Excuse me.  Were you writing registration numbers of each and every car, or were you looking for cars with South African registration numbers?

You see in your statement you say that you were given registration numbers to go and find certain vehicles, now that's quite different to what you're telling us now.  Has someone read this statement to you?
Well I think we should give you an opportunity to refresh your memory, to read this statement, because otherwise your evidence is going to be completely mixed up.

Mr Chairperson, I specifically did not read any statements to Mr Hardien.  If the Commission requests this, I will.  I did not want to do it because I did not want to create certain ideas in his mind which will be disputed at a later stage.  I wanted him to testify on his own memory and I realise it happened a long time ago, but because of that and the things that have been said, I did not want to read the statements to him that he lied about before and will now be stated as the truth.  If the Commission however thinks that it's wise to do it, I will do it.
Well let's just ask this question, did you lie in these statements?
The one that was made in Secunda.
The one that was made when you were in detention.  You made a number in detention, but there was a final one that was made that was signed at Secunda.

And in that statement you say well you did lie before but now you want to tell the full truth, because you realise it's better to come clean and just tell the truth.  Did you tell the truth in that statement?

Alright.  And then in the interview with our staff, our Investigation Team, Mr Khoisan and Mr Petersen, do you remember you had an interview with them in August 1997?  Zenzile Khoisan and Deon Petersen, from our office.
I can remember the name Zenzile.
And he sat with you, presumably in a room somewhere with a tape recorder and he asked you a whole lot of questions which were recorded and your answers were recorded.

But he did not tell me that it was recorded, was being record.  He arrived there and I chased him away because I told him I trust no-one and I believe no-one and at a later stage he arrived again and he showed me a name of somebody, of who he was.  I've chased him away about three times from my house, because he was there more than once.

Well this seemed to be a very long discussion because it's goes for literally 30 pages of typing and there are a whole lot of questions and answers here that are recorded.  You don't remember that at all?
I recall that I spoke to him and I just wanted him to leave.  I told him anything so that I can get rid of him, because I didn't trust anyone.
So you lied to him as well?
Yes, I told him - he can come and testify here, I told him: "It's a lot of shit this, I do not want you here, because I cannot trust you, you come here with different people every time."
Well then we may as well proceed on this basis.
Right.  Now you were in South West Africa, you had to take down registration numbers, were you tasked to commit arson, to slash people's tyres?  Were you told to do that as well, Mr Hardien?
They told me to make friends and I can make friends quite easily, people in the area who can show me around, and I became in touch with the people who lived there.
For how long were you in South West Africa?
I cannot recall if it was a week or a week or two, or three.  I cannot really say.
And how many people did you befriend?

I cannot say exactly but there were the people I met at a friend of mine from the Cape, I met a lot of people in the night-clubs, if they hear you're from the Cape, you make a lot of new friends quite easily.
And why did you make friends, what was the purpose?

They knew the place, they know it better than I do, they can go and show certain areas to me and I told at a certain stage kombis will come and where will they meet.  I do not know the place, so I had to make use of people there to show where's this street, where's this place, where's that place.  Otherwise I wouldn't have known where these places were.
Well did they take you to these places and show you where these kombis were?

Yes, they showed me where the meetings were going to be held, they told me in this street the taxis will come through and the cars will come through or pass through this street.  I think it was probably because of the elections that was going on there.
Sir, to tell you the truth, I do not know or I cannot remember.
You said you met a friend there as well that assisted you in taking down registration numbers and so forth, is that right?
Yes, he's from the Cape, he's got a business there.
And did you meet him in the Cape, or did you meet him in South West Africa?
I met him in South West.
And he wrote down registration numbers of people, do you know whose registration numbers he wrote down for you?
I did not hear that question, can you just repeat it.
In your statement you said this one Coloured man that helped you, he also assisted you in getting registration numbers of cars and so forth, can you remember that?
And that you gave this to Mr Slang van Zyl, remember that?
And what did Mr Slang van Zyl tell you?  Where did you meet him at this stage?
I think I phoned him.  I do not think I met him, I think I phoned him.
And what did you tell him?
I told him I got the registration numbers that he wanted.
And then?  Did he tell you to come back to Cape Town?
Really I cannot recall if I was supposed to stay or come back, I cannot remember, but I did not stay there for very long.  I cannot remember if he told me to come back or not.

Well how was it that you came back?  Did your money run out and then you decided to come home?  Or did you have a discussion with him and he said: "That you for the numbers, bring them to me at a certain place", or ...?

My money did not run out, I do not know if he phoned me or I phoned him but I had to come back then.  It could be that he possibly told me to come back, but my money did not run out, no.   But I spoke to him about the registration numbers, but I cannot say exactly if it was that same day or the next day.
Did you have a printout with these numbers on, or were they just hand-written?
I cannot remember if this guy who helped me printed it out or if he wrote in on a piece of paper.  I'm not quite sure.

Because somewhere there was talk about this chap making enquiries at a registration office and getting proper printouts with addresses and registration numbers.  You know, like you can go to the licensing department and get a printout of who owns what vehicle, or stuff like that.  Do you remember something like that?
Mr Hardien, and then anything else in South West Africa that you did?  In relation to Mr Slang van Zyl's instruction, what else can you remember that you did in South West Africa?
Sorry Mr Hardien, just before you proceed, at that stage did you know Mr van Zyl as Mr van Zyl?
What did you know him as, what name did you know him by?

You then returned back home and you said in your statement that you made in Secunda, that about two weeks after that you were in contact with Mr van Zyl and he came to your house.  Can you remember what transpired there?
Can you just repeat, did he come to my house?
You said that in about August '89, he came to visit you at your house.  Or he could have telephoned you, did he telephone you?
He phoned me, he never came to my house.
Right.  And what did he inform you over the telephone.
Okay.  And then it transpired that you met him at the airport, now I want to take you  ...(intervention)
That was probably August '89.  I want to take you to the Athlone Early Learning Centre, where you had met Mr van Zyl at the airport, can you remember that?
How did you know you were supposed to meet Mr van Zyl at the airport?
And what did he tell you?
I must get to the airport.
Did he inform you as to what you were required to do?
Not at that time, not at that moment when he phoned me.
And when you went to the airport, who did you meet there?
When I met him he came out alone and probably a while later Mr Botha arrived.  He did not want me to see Botha and he did not want Botha to see me.
He told me then that there were two bags, one has got a bomb in and I must go and place it in the Early Learning Centre.
And what did you tell him when he told you that?
I did not say anything to him.
Now these two bags, can you describe it for us?
It is a normal heavy sack, a coloured - it looks exactly the same, both looked the same.
And were they both the same weight?
No, the one was empty, the other one had something in it.
And what did he tell you you must do with the bomb?
He told me the bomb was going to be used to frighten the people.
And where did you go to from there?
I went to my house because it was very early.
And where was the bomb at that stage?
With me in my room, and approximately after half an hour I went to the centre.
Did you tell Mr van Zyl as to when the people would be in the centre?
I'm not quite sure if I gave him an exact time, but I did tell him that they will be there in the evening.  I cannot tell you now exactly what the time was though.
Mr Hardien, did you actually look in the bag and see the bomb?
What did you do with the other bag?  Why were there two bags?
Did you take both bags or just the one?
Well why did you take two bags?
Yes, but surely he must have told you to do something with both bags, what was the object of having two bags?  Was one just a present?
And what did Mr van Zyl tell you you must do with the bomb?
I had to go and place it in the centre because the meeting would be that same evening.
And did you place the bomb after you went home?  You went to your house, did you go then to the Athlone Learning Centre to place the bomb?
From the airport I went to my house and I stayed there for a while and from there I went with the bomb to the Early Learning Centre.

Mr Hardien, earlier on at this hearing we went to the centre to take a look at it and it's quite a big centre, there's a number of rooms, were you just told to put it in the centre anywhere, or was anything more specific mentioned as to whereabouts in the centre the bomb should be put?
No, I told them that I'd placed it in the hall.  They did not tell me where I must go and place it.
Did you place it in the hall because that's where the meeting was going to be?
In the hall though, as opposed to in the other offices?
There were meetings in the hall, in the boardroom and I just decided on the hall.
So that was just your decision, no-one told you to put it there, that was just your discretion that you put it there?
So can you explain to us where in the centre you placed the bomb?
The Committee understands, I placed it in the corner, in the right-hand side of the hall - no, sorry, it was the left side of the hall.
That's the hall on the left of the front entrance to the building?
What's called the front entrance, as opposed to the entrance  at the back which is where the parking area is?
No, it was in Springbok Street, just as you explained it now.  It was in the front of the building.  The street is Springbok Street.
And when you placed the bomb in the building, were there people in the building at that time?
Was there nobody in the building?
Surely there was a manager or a watchman or other staff in that building.  Was the whole building completely empty, or was the hall just empty?
Yes, but she said the building, not the hall and that's the problem.  She asked you if the building was empty, not if the hall was empty.
Then I did not understand it right.
That's why I'm clarifying it.  So the hall was empty but there were obviously other people around there?
And what did you do after you placed the bomb?
And did you meet - was there any plan to meet Mr van Zyl again?
Yes, I had to go and meet them, I think it was at the Bellville Holiday Inn.
And then when you met them there, did you all come together, drive in one car or two cars from the Holiday Inn?
And whose car did you drive in?
It was a friend of mine's.
And then what did you do?
How long did you drive around the place for?
I cannot say exactly if it was five or 10 minutes, I cannot say.
And can you explain to us which part around the Early Learning Centre did you drive around?
Mr van Zyl them did not know the area or the place, I drove round the front, right round, because you can circle the whole building and then we went to go and stand at the back of the building.
Did you circle the whole building?
So you could see the back and the front.
Yes, the back and front, correct.
And when you stopped the car, could you see the parking lot or could you see the front of the building?
And then, what were your instructions, what did Mr van Zyl tell you to do then?
I had to go and see if all the people were out, but while we were sitting there people came out, but I went out to go and make sure.
I once again went without Van Zyl and I went to go and ensure that all the people were out.
And did you report back to Mr van Zyl.
Sorry, did you go right into the building?  Did you just stand near the entrance, what happened?
I stood at the door.  You can see if you stand at the door.
And did you look into the hall, did you look in the rest of the building, where did you look?
No, I did not look around in the building, because I spoke to Mr Williams there.
I told him: "Just make sure that everybody's out because I planted a bomb here."
I told him that, my exact words.
We have a Mr Williams here ...(intervention)
And after checking the building you reported this back to Mr van Zyl, is that right?
So did you get into the car again or what happened, can you explain that to us?
I climbed back into the car, yes.
Was that where you could see the parking lot?
Could you tell us about how many metres away from the Early Learning Centre were you parked?  30 metres, 40 metres?
Can you estimate the distance in this court?
It wasn't far.  As you enter, on the corner of the road, the road runs in a circle, the Committee has been there, so the Committee will understand if I say from the corner to the building.
Were you at the inspection in loco when we went there, Mr Hardien?  Were you with us when we went there?
No, no, I'm talking when we went as the Committee.  Were you there when we were there?
I stood at my flat and I saw all of you there.

Oh, okay.  But I'm sure I know the corner that you're speaking about, you've got that sort of circle, the road that goes in a circle and it's just - it's not far from the entrance to where the car park is.
It's approximately - we did take a measurement and it was pointed out to us.  I've forgotten the exact measurements, but it's about 30 metres or so.
And then Mr Hardien, you got back into the car with Mr Slang van Zyl, is that right?
And what did you do then, did you drive around the block, what did you do?
We sat and waited until all the cars were gone.
For me it was hundred percent certain that everyone had left, because there were no more cars.
From where you were could you see that there were no more cars in the parking lot?
That is correct, because I knew the place like the back of my hand.
And then, who pressed the - what happened thereafter?
Then Mr van Zyl - you'll understand if I say a calculator, because to me it looked like a calculator, Mr Botha pressed it and I took them to the airport.
Sorry.  Did he press it while you were at the back of the hall?
No, I was with him in the car.
Yes, but was the car at the back of the hall still, where you'd been observing from?
It was at the back, we were parked at the back where I said we were standing.
Was there any problem with the calculator?
I cannot recall if there was a problem.
So Van Zyl gave the calculator to Botha, who pressed it, is that right?  As far as you can remember.
And then you heard the bomb, is that right?
What did you do after the bomb exploded?
I took Mr van Zyl and them to the airport.
And did you go back to the Athlone Early Learning Centre after the incident?
Now we know that you received money for this operation, can you tell the Committee how much you received for your involvement?
Was that the only amount you received?
Why I'm asking you this is because you - first tell me, when did you receive the R18 000, was it before the incident or after the incident?
And how long after the incident?
If I recall correctly it was two weeks.

That amount of R18 000, Mr Hardien, was it a previously agreed amount, or when you got it was it a surprise to you, the amount?  Were you expecting R18 000 at the time that you performed as you did with regard to the bomb?
Nothing was discussed regarding money before the time.
Were you expecting to be paid?
Did you actually count the money?
But at any time did you sit down and count it and make sure it was exactly R18 000?
And after the Athlone Early Learning Centre, did you have contact with Mr Slang van Zyl again thereafter?
Was that the last time that you had dealings with Mr Slang van Zyl?

You also spoke about a place ... arson committed in homes, can you recall that incident where UDF members were using a certain printing place to get their pamphlets and materials and so forth?  Do you remember ever talking about that or being involved in arson there?
Now you said - are you sure Mr Hardien, that you went to South West Africa only once?

Mr van Zyl stated that he sent to South West Africa and that your contact person was Mr Burger in South West Africa and he was going to give you instructions there as to what to do, did you ever meet Mr Burger in South West Africa?
I don't know Mr Burger.  I cannot recall.

Because in your statement to the TRC Investigative Unit, I know you said that you lied there, you didn't tell the truth, that when you went to South West Africa there were people like Mr Burger there and then this Greek man, Kouvaris, can you remember anything like that?
And then just in relation to Peaches, did Peaches ever go to South West Africa?
I don't know, you'll have to ask that at Gate 9, I don't know.
What do you mean by Gate 9?
Because I don't know if he was there, go and ask him.
Because in your Section 29 you stated that Peaches also had missions to accomplish in South West Africa.
I don't know anything about that.
Right.  The next incident I want to talk to you about is, can you recall that Mr Peaches had informed you about the Dullah Omar incident?
Once again I don't know, I can't recall.  If you want to know, I think Gate 9 has a telephone number.  If he told me, I would have told you.
Why I'm asking you this is because you said to our Investigative Unit that in relation to the Dullah Omar incident, Peaches was tasked to kill Mr Omar.  What is your comment?
Once again, what I said to Zenzile was a lot of shit, because I just wanted them to get away from me.
You also stated that there was a certain woman, a domestic worker in the Omar house that assisted him, what is your comment about that?

I don't even know who worked for Mr Omar.  The other day I saw Mr Omar for the first time.  He's never had such a discussion with me.  I don't even know who Peaches was working for, I only found out subsequently who he was working for.

Just one second.
	Are you saying that this transcript of a discussion with you is just totally fabricated by Mr Petersen and Mr Khoisan?  Are you saying they didn't record what they spoke to you about and this transcript is just total fabrication?

I know they came to speak to me, but I don't know anything about a recording.  If they made a recording, then they did so.  But once again, I didn't want those people with me because I couldn't trust anybody at that stage anymore, because they didn't show me any kind of identification indicating who they were.
Did you ever go to the office of the Truth Commission, in Adderley Street in Cape Town?
And did you sit down there and talk to Mr Zenzile?

You see, I'm going to read you the first paragraph of this thing, where Mr Zenzile's talking.  He says here
"Mr Isgak Hardien, thank you very much for attending the interview here at the TRC.  We would like to discuss the activities and allegations against the former CCB and specifically we would like to discuss the role that you played during that time."
Do you remember that he sat down with you and placed all of that?
I recall that he sat down and spoke, but I don't know whether it was that or what it was.

Well this was an interview that was specifically recorded and this is how he started it off, and he made reference to your Section 29 affidavit and he asked you a whole lot of questions, it must have taken quite a long time, in the office of the Truth Commission.  Do you remember that?
I recall that he came to fetch me and that we went to the offices.
Yes, and this was in August 1997, some three years ago.
I cannot recall when it took place.
Yes, but it's not very long ago, it's a couple of years, surely you remember that.
I know that he came to fetch me and I telephoned him again.
Now what I want to know is, when you went to the Truth Commission, why did you go there, why did you go and sit down with him in an office there and talk to him about all these things?

He was at my house and he came to tell me that he was from the TRC, and then I said to him: "No, I don't trust you."  He returned, probably after a week and then I asked him, before we went to any office: "Listen, you said you're from the TRC, I've seen it on the TV, I've seen it in the papers, all the people, I've seen this thing about amnesty, where do I fit in?"  Then he asked me whether I would be prepared to accompany him to the offices because he would assist me.  And that is how it happened that we went to the office.  And then I found out that he came to me with a whole bunch of stories, because then he wanted to know whether I was ever at certain places and if I hadn't phoned myself, I wouldn't even have known about this business.  I telephone Lynn myself, no-one told me: "You have to be at such and such a place, this is going to be happening."  I used my own mind and phoned people and made enquiries and said: "Listen, I've heard my name on the radio ...(intervention)
I'm asking you about your interview with Khoisan, what happened afterwards is a different story.  I want you to focus your mind on your interview.  Do you understand?

Yes, I understand.  I went with him to the offices, but I cannot recall what exactly we discussed.  He asked me questions and I simply gave him answers for the sake of answering.  Do you understand me?
Yes.  So when you said to him that you knew Peaches for a long time, from primary school ...(intervention)
I've known Peaches, he's been operating with me since Sub A.
So that wasn't a lie, that wasn't a lie, that's the truth.
Yes, he wanted to know about Peaches and I said I've known Peaches since Sub A.
Yes.  And that you said before he was murdered he was a member of the Dixie Boys, is that true?
Peaches was a member of the Dixie Boys, it was impossible to hide that.
Well you see, here you say you were higher than him, were you lying about that?
Sorry, Mr Lax, where are you?  When you say "here"?
Page 160.  That is the first page of the taped conversation.

In fact where he says he was higher than him is a bit further on in that interview.
	But in the interview that's what you say, that you were a senior to him.  You avoid saying that you were the leader, but you say that you were senior to him.  Was that just lies?
No, he may have misinterpreted what I saw.  All of them respected me, that is what I tried to convey to him, every last Dixie.

It's page 161, Mr Lax.
	Mr Hardien, then I just want to take you back to your Section 29 detention, how did it come about that you were detained?  Can you explain that to us?

I can just recall that they came to fetch me and the next thing I saw I was in John Vorster Square and they told me: "Your friend Peaches is on the other side, but he'll be going home today", and then it was said that I was the one who planted the bomb and they said fine and he went home and I stayed.
And was Mr Slang van Zyl also detained when you were detained at that time?
I don't know if it was at the same time, but he was there.
Because in one of the statements it's stated that you actually shared the same cell for a short while.  Can you remember that?
No, I don't recall that, you couldn't share a cell.
Sorry Chairperson, could Ms Coleridge point out to us in which statement it's alleged they shared the same cell?  You know to just put it to this ...

Chairperson, I will find the reference and I will make it available, Chairperson.
	Mr Isgak can you tell us, all in all, how much money did you receive from the CCB?
